div.head: The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 1 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship's accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.
Subject to the usual 25% reduction for returning.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday until 4 June, and then every Tuesday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.

The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. Combined fare to London by sea and train de luxe via Brindisi or via Marseilles £ 19.4.11.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for SUDAN, SUAKIN, direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidan, Aden. Intermediate steamersdo not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yamboas required. and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: THE NATIONAL HOTEL, CAIRO.
div.p: One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotals in the Metropolis. Situated in Sharia
Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fashionable quarter. Stands in its
own grounds with garden and lawn tennis grounds at back. Over 350 rooms and 5 saloons.
Magnificent salle à manger. Handsome covered promenade verandah, 80 yards long. Highest
class cuisine, electric light throughout and lifts. English comforts. Rooms and apartments
at prices to suit every one. For further particulars to GENERAL MANAGER, Cairo.

The house onumittee of the British Club will be "At Home" at the club to members and their friends on the occasion of Empire Day, 24th iost., from 5 to 7.30 p.m. Ladies are specially invited.

Mohamed Abdalls, druggist of El Seronguieh (Cairo), has been St.of P.T. 50 with costs and bad hia shop closed and its contents seised for practising without a licence. Amin Pahmi Ssbbour, doctor of Zagarig, has been fined a similar amount and been subjected to the same penalties for the sale of drugs of inferior quality.

Those who wish to participate in a most interesting and instructivo representation coaid not do better than visit the above-named cinematograph exhibition during the present week Tbo programme is an exceptionally good one and the various scenes are exceedingly well reproduced. Those of New Zealand and tho Carnival cf Nice are alone well worthy of a visit.
Train Breaks Down.

Passengers leaving the Barrage for Cairo by the 6.20 p m. train on Sunday had an unpleasant experience. No water was taken in at the Barrage station by the train from Cairo, which broke down on the return journey between Shoubra and Kaliouh, with the result that a train had to bo sent down to take up the passengers, who only reached Cairo at 9.20 p m
Egyptian Date Palms for Ceylon.

Tho Khedivial Agricultural Society lately forwarded to the Ceylon Agticoltoral society, with their compliments, a consignment of suokers of some ol the test varieties of the date palm to to found in Egypt. The Royal Botanic Garden at Peradeniya baa received a couple of dozen suckers of six varieties. These are to te dispatched to suitable localities in the Island.
The Sultan's Methodse.

Soon after Lord—then Sir Philip—Carrie was appointed Ambassador at Constantinople, 4he Sultan learnt that Lady Currie ("Violet Pane") had written poems. His' Majesty, in order to win the favour of the Ambassador, a correspondent states in a morning paper, gave an order that "Violet Pane's" poems shoald be the texj-book for Koglish in the elementary schools of the Ottoman Empire.
Murder at Marlout.

A Bedouin woman of Mariout informed the Marks authorities threo days ago that her 'brother was pissing. After due enquiry the police suspected a Bedouin named said Murajia and his father, Murejia Rubeim, of having dooe away with the man. But both the father and the son could not be found and their whereabouts are still unknown. The body of the reordered Bedouin, which is thunght to have been baried in the sand, has not yet been discovered
A "Miracle" at Sohag.

The following interesting account of a " miracle, " which we reproduce textually, is, furnished by a Sohag correspondent In a conversation with a man, that fell from the train, seven years ago and became a cripple; but now cored,, he stated thus :— "I spent this period of life in the greatest troubles. doing no work, but asking for alms all the , time ; but, a few days ago. I slept in the Coptic church, finding no other refuge, where I dreamed of two angels, who. with the weapons , ot kindness, struck my legs. The angels, as he, stated, after doing their work, sent a young gentle lady, who washed me all over with ointment; and in the morning. as if secondly born, ( I became completely-cured cabbie of working for life. The rumour is spread all over the province, for the mao is personally known; and as — reported with a slight difference by the native press.
Captain Dawson's Action.

Captain Charles Herbert Dawson, late of the Army Servioe Corps. who is well known in Alexandria, having been once stationed here, succeeded in his action for libel against certain English newspapers last week. During the war plaintiff superintended tho shipment of hay "from Liverpc/rf to South Africa, and the litigation arose out of comments on proceedings id the Hoore of Commons in regard to defective hay. The jury fonnd in favour of plaintiff, awarding the damages as follows : Against "Reynold's Newspaper," £50 ; against the "Western Daily Mercury, £15 ; against the , Scotsman," £5 and egaim.t the ' Weekly Timhsand Echo £10- Judgment was accord- ingly pronounced for plaintiff, with costs against defendants. In hia summing up to the jury Mr. Justice Backnill taid that they must not baso their damages npon the treatment the plaintiff bad received at the hands of the War Offi'e. He admitted that no one could be so cold blooded as Hot to be touched by the plantiff evidence if the way in which be had been treated.

div.head: THE SINAI BOUNDARY
div.p: RESTORATION OF PILLARS
DEPARTURE OF COMMISSION
London, May 21
The bourdary pillars at El Ilsfah have bee replaced on the spot from where they were removed. The Turkish force at El Rafah bar been reduced and withdrawn to some distance northwards.

We understand that the Egyptian Boundary Commission will consist of the followin members : Miralai E. R.' Owen Bey, Ibrahim Fathi Pasha, and Naoum Bey 8hokeir, con missioners ; Capt. F. Brakenridge, Medici Staff, EA., medical other; Messrs, B. 1 Wade aDd B. P. Keo'ing, of the Surve Department, with ten Egyptian sobordinatei who will carry ont the actual snrveyin operations and undertake all such scientific operations the time at their disporal allowi The members of theCommissionleaveto morro' and Wednesday for Suez, whence they will proceed to Akaba and delimit north to El Arish. Ten coastguards will escort the part)

The Turkish Commissioners are Pebm Pasha and Mmsffer Bey, who wore appointed Frontier Commissioners by the Ottoman Qc vernment at an early stage of the dispoti and whose oonduct in visiting Cairo aDd de parting without giving any official sign life was much commented on at the time.

div.head: THE FRONTIER DELIMITATION
div.p: A writer in a London contemporary remarks:— Even the eviction of the Turk from Egyptian d territory by the menace of armed fordqd 3f fails to obtain for us more than, amoral redress, while leaving the question as open as lolore to further complication and intrigue by our acceptance of a possible rectification froqiisr ro definitively indicated in 1892 Upon this point all the opponents of our position i tv Egypt may n now legitimately concentrate tbeir efforts, and of in winning this concession from Groat Britain iy Turkey ar d her backers may withdraw with the It smug satisfaction that their well planned eftour- p sion into Egyptian territory has in no wise been it barren cf results. The validity of the former delimitation has been snccessfolly challenged. A qnestion has been opened for futnre debate, and, from the Turkish point of view, everything is yet possible—even a Conference

div.head: TRIBUNAL AT EL ARISH.
div.p: The correspondent of "Al Mokattam" at El Arish states that the inhabitants of the town are greatly pleased by the establishment of a tribunal under the presidency of Kaimakam Parker Bey.

div.head: THE CLIMB DOWN
div.p: The Porte's submission, it seems, was not made readily.

After agreeing on Satnrday to evacuation and delimitation in principle, it objected to tho word "delimitation," which it considered implied the existence of a frontier, whereas, it maintained, Egypt was a part of Turkey. It also objected to the basis of delimitation proposed by Great Britain—namely, the El Rafah-Akaba line.

On these points the Porte was obstinate till Sunday night, when Sir Nicholas O'Connr called on. the Turkish Poreign Minister and tho Grand Virier, atid made an important statement which caused the Turkish Government to realise its perilous position.
In view of the assnrarces given by the Ottoman Ministers, Sir Nicholas O'Conor consented to wait another twelve hours.
An exciting night followed at the Palaoe, and in the early hours of Monday morning a special oonncil was summoned which decided upon complete compliance with the demands

div.p: The Italian Government intends to establish . a Consulate at Khartoum and another at Port 1 Sudan. Lieut. Carlo Rossetti will most probably be appointed Consol at the Sudan Capital.

div.head: CORPORATION OF WESTERN EGYPT
div.p: The rails of the Western Oasis railway have now been laid up to Kilometre 4.5 thus a quarter of tho distance between thi Nile Valley and the Oasis of Kbarga ran dov be traversed by train. The permanent way is being laid at the rate of one kilometre per day, while the for motion work in the hands of a contractor ii two kilometres in advance of the rail-head The telephone line is being erected to keep pace with the laying of the rails.

div.head: THE PLAGUE
div.p: During the week ending on the 20th inst, thirty cares ofp'agne were reported throughout Egypt, i.e 8 in the Deshna district, 14 in Samalont, 2 in Bibeh, 5 in Ghirgek, ar,d 1 at Port Said. Since the lst January 316 cases of plague have- been reported, as against 53 in the same period in 1905, and 500 in 1904. One case was reported at Samalout yesterday.

div.head: BLIND SCHOOL ZEITOUN
div.p: Lord Cromer, in his Report, referring to the Blind Sch ool at Zsitonn, states that a long lease of the premises has been granted by Mr. and Miss Armitsge, the proprietors, at a nominal rental, with right of porchaee on advantageous conditions. An appeal to the public for funds is meeting with a very satisfactory reception. The Egyptian Government has 'granted an annual sum of L.B. 500 in aid of the institution. A teacher skilled in industrial work for the blind has lately arrived from England, and arrangements are being made by the corqmittee for renting an additional workshop .aiyl day school in Cairo for the popils who have paasfd, or are about to pass, though the educational curriculum, and for tb6se who, for age or other reason, cannot bo admitted as boarders. Besides basket end chair making, other suitable varieties of work will be introduced, snch as the making ot mats, brushes, etc.. Tho number of boarders has increased to 27. There are also five day popils. There is at present accommodation fol 35 boarders, and this number wdl probably soon be reached. The school continues to publish Arabio works in the embosed Braille type use of the blind.

Uniforms have recently been presentes for the use of the boys, who are regularly drilled by Egyptian non-commissioned officers. Two prominent members of the Jewish community have lately joined the committee, which was previously composed entirely of Moslems and Christians (European and Native.)

div.head: PROPOSED TROPICAL SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
div.p: WORK OF CAIRO SCHOOL.

Dr. Reginald Harrison, P.R.C.8 , writes as follow to the "British Medical Journal':— a Your account of Lord Cromer's report On Egypt will be read with interest by all who have watched the progress that has taken plaoe in its development and iglgtiem to oor own and other oontriea. Reference is made to the advantages that are likely to follow the recognition of the Medical Scbool by the two ^ Royal Collages of Bogland, and the mark that their conjoint diploma will put on Bgyptian students who are enabled to obtain it after examination. To give effect to this "it has been arrange that a delegate of the British Royal Colleges of Physicians and Surgeons should be present annually at the examinations held in Cairo, and that the students who! pass those examinations when the de'egate ia.prrsent . should enjoy the same advantage as if the corresponding examinations had been passed in London."

From my residence in Egypt for a portion oi two recent winter, and the opportunities I bad of making myself acquainted with the facilities ' for stodying medicine and snrgery in Cairo, I am strongly of opinion that further important developments should be enoooraged. I hope this may take the form of a tropical school of medicine in Cairo in connexion with the medical school, and open to all nationalities.

From the British point of view such an institution would offer many advantages. In the first plaoe, Cairo is within a week's journey from Bngland, and, in- the next, it is on the great highway to British India, to Australis, f to parts of Afrioa and other places in which 1 we have large interests. In addition to educating medical students, each could be made available for oivil, naval, and medical practioners desirous of obtaining this form of post graduate study.

If the Egyptian student may now count his time spent there for examination purposes, there seems no reason why the latter persons may not do so, in _ the pursuit of farther professional knowledge and experience. Of tbe advantages of Cairo as a place of study for tropical diseases I Deed hardly say a word. Many types of medical and surgical diseases may be seen there in their most gente and varied forms, and the facilities offered by a Urge hospital with a 'well equipped medical school and museum attached, with Eoglish speaking professors 5 (including hospital physicians and surgeons) leave nothing to be desired.

In the volume of reports recently issued by the Kasr El Ainy Hospital will be found 1 mcch valuable information and original research, made on the spot, relating to tropical disease. Those of us who were fortunate enough to be present at the First Bgyptian Medical Coogress (1902) will not forget the personal i encouragement that great cosmopolitan assembly received from H.H. the Khedive, and ; the numerons scientific attractions and no- - velties provided for us.Though excellent work is being done in the t tropical schools of London and Liverpool, this should be added to by similar efforts in places which are themselves liable to tropical diseases and their causes.

Lord Cromer thus refers to the School of Medicine in hie Uat anneal Report : — During the past year, the number of itnd- ente who joined the Sohool of Medicine wae 37, of whom one wae a pharmaoentical student.'rhe number who obtained their diplomas was 17. There ere at present 116 students in the School, of whftytwo are attached to the phar maceutioal seetkn.

As the result of some negotiations in which Mr. Reginald Harrison took a leading part and materially assisted the cause of Egypt, it has 1 been arranged that a delegate of the British ' Royal Colleges of Physioians and Surgeons should be present annually at the examina- ' tions held in Cairo, and that Jjhe students who pass those examinations when the delegate is ' present should enjoy the same advantage as if the corresponding examinations had been passed in London. The advantages of the new arrangement to Egyptian students of medicine will be very great, for amongst the people of this country there still exists a strong prejudice in favour of employing a medical man who holds a European qoalification. This School now possesses a staff of highly qualified professors, under whose auspioea various scientific work of much interest and importance was earned out during the past year.

div.head: A LOST GOSPEL
div.p: CHRIST'S SERMON ON OUTWARD PIETY
IMPORTANT MS. DISCOVERY

The announcement that a fragment of a lost Gospel had been discovered by Dr. b.p. ; Orenfell and Dr. A. S. Hunt on the site of Oxyrbyuchus. in Upper Egypt, is oausing a \ sensation in theological oiroles wbiob bids fair | to rival that which followed the finding of the famous "sayings" of Christ on the same spot.

A representative of the "Daily Mail'' saw the "find' at Queen's College, Oiiord. It ie e. i tiny fragment of vellum, perforated by worms and yellowed by sixteen oratories, but still perteotly legible. The writing ie almost microscopically minute, but the Greek characters and even the scarlet of the initial letter still show op vividly.

"It is certainly no part of an extant Gospel," said Dr. Gieofeil, "bal its theological value 1 must leave to theologians. It is unusually ] well written from a literary point i of view. Thoro are some 300 words on the page.

"It begins in the middle of a speech. Jeens acd his disciples have entered the Temple end 1 have met a Pharisee, who rebukes them for omitting to go through some elaborate ceremonial of ablation. Jesas asks whit the Pharisee has done, and the reply describes (the process J of purification minutely.
"This is deeply interesting 'to ds, for no „ previous suthority gives detai's of such a ceremony as the Pharisee describes.

"There follows a power!ll and eloquent denunciation by Jesna of mere outward purification. He says that He and His disciples baye t been pnrifisd with the 'living water' or water y of life.' Another new point brought oot by the c fragment is the first mention of a portion of the f Temple called tbe 'Hsgnentorion,' or plaoe of fc porifioation. This, too. has never been spoken i; of before, so far as is knbwn."
Oxyrbynchos had onaeu monasteries, with J 4,noo monks, and Dr. Grenfell and Dr. Hunt , have been working in monads which were once £ the dnst heaps of the city.

div.head: THE SYRIAN GOSPEL
div.p: Mrs. A. S.Lewis writes to the "Times" with reference to the Palimpsest of the 8yrian Gospels discovered by her in 1892 in the Convent of Saint Catherine on Mount Sinai, stating that when she revisited the oonvenQin 1902 she fonnd that leaf No. 101 of the MS, containing Mark il, 21 iii., 21, had been abstracted from the special box in which it was kept. The monks were aware of the loss, and had their suspicions as to the identity of the thief, but had taken no steps to recover the leaf from fears that snch action might lead to its destruction. It was rianidsd to give all possible publicity to the occurrence, and Mrs. Lewis published in the ' Expository "Times" of April, 1902, an appeal to the possessor to return the leaf, and thus by a timely act of reparation to atone for an aot the full significance of which he bad perhaps not realized. The appeal remained without etlect'Tor' four years, but on May 4 last Mrs. Lewis received from the Archbishop of Moont Sinai, Porphyrins II., the welcome intelligence that the leaf had been restored to- its plaoe. Mrs. Lewis adds that she has no knowledge of what has led to this happy result, and that by the terms of ler appeal she is pledged to ask no questions.

The company shall, if called apon so to do y the Director General of Cnstoms at any me within ten years of the date of the agree- ient, erect on and over the whole or any part : Block B a substantial two-storeyed masonry ailding comprising a warehouse and offices in :oordance with plana to be prepared by the impany and submitted to and approved by ie Cnstoms Administration and also the dministration of Ports and Lights.

At the expiration or sooner determination r the lease of the 2nd day of Dooember, 1899, i extended by the present agreement, all uildings and all fixed appliances now erected r hereafter to be erected on any part of the res comprised in the said lease (which area :all be taken to inolnde Block C) shall be anded over to the Government in a state of uod repair and shall thereafter become the b'olnte property of the Government without syment of any compensation whatever. .

All powers expressed by the lease of the end day of December, 1899, to bs exeroireablo j y the Administration of Railways, Telegraphs ad the Port of Alexandria shall henoeforVard ! a exerciseable by the Director-General of orts and Lights.

The company shall as far as possible and in agreement srith the Director General of lustoms, provide proper and sufficient storage ocommodatibn outside the Customs enolosnre t Alexandria for the bonding of goods dis- barged at any quay which, in the opinion of he Director-General of Customs; is too iistant from the existing premises of the company for those premises to be available

(3rd class) of the Osmanieh on Mustapha Sirri Bey, ex Moudir of Beni Souef and Hodgson Bey, formerly of the Railway Administration and the rank of Moutemaiz on. Sheikh Abdul Hamid el-Bakri, son-in-law of the late Sayid Abdel Kbaiik Bl-Sadat, has been appointed by the Khedive as snooenor to his father-in law in the sheikhahip of "Wafaieh," and been granted the privilege* which the deoeased possessed.

We regret tosnnounoe the death, which took plaoe at his son's residence in Paris yesterday, of M. Ei Laurens, the well known cigarette manufacturer. M. Laurens was for ' forty yeirs resident in Egypt, where be began bis career aa a stockbroker, and subsequently, in 1888, founded the Khedive cigarette manufactory, which be formed into a limited liability company in 1896. His philanthropy was well known, Especially towards bis employes, who will lose in him in a real friend.

div.head: FRANCO ITALIAN FETE.
div.p: The Franco Italian Fete organised by the "Dante Alighieri" Society and others in aid tf tb$ sofferers doriog the recent disastrous eruption of Moont Veiavins and those of the late colliery catastrophe in Franoe, was opened in the "French Girden" on Saturday last, and has been visited by some thousands of persons.

The "Garden" hta been most tastefally decorated with hundreds of ooloared electric lamps for the occasion, and on catering it is difficult to believe that the fairy like spectacle which- meets one's gaze can possibly be the transformation of the desolate pieoe of groand which has too long remained sn eye-sore in the city.

The entertainment provided for the patrons of the festival is of a very varied character, and consists of songs, choruses, gymnastics, an assault atarms, firework display, a cinematograph exhibition, and a reproduction in fireworks of the eruption of Vesuvius. The various performances are very wall gone through, and for the benefit, or otherwise, of those who are icc'ined to "try their lock" numerous attractive- looking devices are provided for the purpose, including the ever-present "petits-chevaux" and "rouge-et-noir." Several lotteries appeared to be well patronised, and muaio was discoursed by two excellent bands. Altogether the festival is well worth a visit, and should prove a welopme answer to that oft-askad question in Alexandria, "Where can we go The garden is open each afternoon at 4 and each evening et 9 o'clock.
This evening, the hand of the Royal Dublin Fusiliers will perform iu the garden, by kind permission of Col. Bird; D. S. 0:, and the officers.

div.head: SHARKS
div.p: A correspondent writes No little excitement prevailed' ths other day among the bathers in Stanley Bay by the appoaraoee on the distant horison of the draaefad dorsal fin or a shark. As with the case of the bull iu the sbina shop, ths bsy was speedily vacated of its amphibians. The dreaded monster, however, turned to be ma/ish : the fiotion of a fertile imagination.

Talking about sharks, there is now a large demand for their skins in Germany, where a process has been discovered for tanning and making them pliable. Tbe North Pacific shark is prized for the oil of its liver, which besides being a splendid labrioant is a remedy for rheumatism ; their fids and tails are also considered delicaoies by the Pacifi Islanders and the Chinese, who import large quantities. The fin produces an isinglass which is rqnal to that Borope. The exports of shark fius trom the Persian Gulf to China last year amounted to B.050 pounds.

Here are suggestions of practical commercial value to the directors of the Mex sham bles who feed large numbers of sharks with their refase.Shirk fin sonp or fritters would introduce a novel feature into our monotonous menus.

div.head: TRIBUNAUX MIXTES.
div.p: FOURS CRÉMATOIRES.

Nous lisons dans un journal du Caire d'hier. "Il y a quelques temps le gouvernement avait émis le projet de constructionde fours crématoirs pour incinérer les corps. La Cour d'appel mixte dans un arrêt rendu aucun arret hier à ce sujet, mais avait, dans son assemblée générale de 5 Mai, appruve le projet relatif aux fours crematoires en lui apportant quelques modifications. Ce projet paraltra, d'ailleurs, incessamment àl'Officiel.

div.head: LE MUSEE DU CAIRE
div.p: Le musee du Caire est le plus riche museo d'antiquites egyptiennes et l'univers entier. Fonde a Boulaq, transporte ensuite a Ghizeh, il a trouve recemment dans les trouveaux quartiers du Caire, une installation somptuese et parfaite.

M. Maspero raconte, dans la Rem (d'Egypte et d'orient, l'biatoire de oe musé histoire où la France tient une place glorieuse Dés 1830, Champollion avait proposé, sat succès, à Mohammed Ali d'organiser un servit des antiquités égyptiennes.

Cinq ans plus tan notre consul général Mimant obtenait la création tion d'un musée qu'on établit près de 1 E»b qui ref it en dépôt un certain nombre c choses, mais qui u'eut jamais de conservateur ni même de gardien. Le vrai fondateur d musée fat Mariette. Après sa découverte d Serapeum vers 1852, des rivalités et di intrigues l'avaient obligé de quitter l'Egypte, y rentra en IÇ57. grace à l'appui du prim Napoléon et de M. de Lesseps, et l'anm suivante Nubar pacha le nomma directeur d service des antiquités.

Le premier soin Mariette fut d'empêcher l'exportation de ci antiquités et d'entreprendre lui-même 1 fouilles qu'il supposait devoir être les pic productives. Il rassembla sous de simples hangars ses trouvailles de Memphis, d'Abydos et de Thèbes. Ce n'est qu'en 1863, après di négociations sans fin, q i'il eut la joie d'inaugurer musée de Boulaq. Tout le reste de i vie fut occupé à défendre .oe musée, so oontre le Nil qui parfois l'envahissait, soit oo tre les générosités du Khédive, toujours prêt faire des politesses aux puissances au détriment des trésors de Boulaq.

Lorsque Mariette fouillait à Abydos, un vieux cheik s' merveillait de la précision avec laquelle dirigeait le1 recherches: "Je n'ai jamais quitté ce village, et pourtant je ne savais pas l'existence de ce mur.. Quel Age as-tu donc,toi qui l'es rappelé î—Trois mille an», répondit Mariette — Alors, reprit le cheik, il faut que t sois on grand saint pour avoir l'air si jeune. Ce grand saint n'est pas aussi connu ,^u' mériterait de l'être. M. Maspero montrait u jour à un personnage de marque l'inscription placée k l'entrée du nouveau musée : Mariett 1821-1851 : "Je un savais [Ma, dit lo person nage, que le fondateur do marée fût--une femme."

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'Aui à midi et demie) Marché très calme; presque tontes les valeurs fléchissent ions le trop grand nombre d'offres et celui très restreint des demandes. On ne sait trop à quoi attribuer cette accalmie que l'approche de la morte saison ne justifie que faiblement.
L'Agricole faiblit de I'16k9 8/1. La National de 1/8 a 26. La Delta Light reste ferme à 12 acheteurs. Le coupon est, comme on le sait, distribué en juin.

La Daïra perd 1/16 17 3/16. La Brasserie des Pyramides recule de 2 francs a 124. La Cassa di Sconto fléchit de 1/2 a 215 l'ancienne, la nouvelle a 210, la Banque d'Athènés de 1 fr. a 150 ; les Urbaines perdent 1/16 a 6 1/8.
Par contre la Ramleh R-ailway gagne 1/l6 i 6 13/16 et les Tramways d'Alexandrie 1 franc a 341.
La Béhéra avance de 1/4 a 35 1/2. La Delta Land perd 3/32 a 3 7/8. La Sait & Soda gagne 3 pence a 21.3. Les markets sont échangés et cotent en clôture 27-6 gagnant 1 shelling sur le prix d'hier.

div.head: CIRCULAIREH. DE VRIES ET BOUTINY
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUE

Le Caire, Lundi 21 Mai. A Londres, le Consolidé anglais a clôturé avant-hier, invarié à 89 3/1. L'Unifiée, National Bank, l'Agricole et la Daira ont égal ment conservé leurs cours de la veille. Seul la Delta Light est renseignée en reprise do I, à 12 1/4.
A Paris, l'action Crédit Foncier Egyptian est demeurée inchangée à 772. La Banque d'Athènes a regagné 1 franc a 151.
Ici, nous avons eu, ce matin, on marche calme, avec très peu de transactions et' sans changements importants dans le cours de la plupart des valeurs.

La National Bank a clôturé a 26 1/8-8/16 l'Agricole à 9 13/16-7/8. La Nile Land a réactionné a 15 1/4 et le Jouissances Baux do Caire se sont revolées 260. L'action Immobilière s'est raffermie 364 ; la part de fondateur est, par contre, ri venue a 600. L'Agricole du Nil a fléchi h 260 la part de fondateur à 7 7/8 15/16.
L'Union Foncière a progressé à 6 1/29/1 Les Omnibus do Caire se sont alourdis 26 3/1 27, et les Khédivial Mail a 31 sh. Dans le groupe des Hôtels, les Nungovich

ont été poussés a 15 3/4, gagnant une demilivre sur leur prix d'avant-hier; l'action nouvelle a haussé a 14 7/8 15/16. Parmi les petites valeurs, les Delta Land it clôturé à 3 15/16-4 ; le i Markets a 26 sb. ; les Sait and Soda à 21 sh. 6 ; Jes New Egyptian a 28 sh. 3 ; les Estâtes a 1 5/3 et leur part de fondateur a 10 1/6 ; les Sucreries 17 francs.
Nous recevons plusieurs lettres par 1e quoMes on nous demande de publier notre avi sur l'état réel du marché financier, ainsi que sur 1er probabilités de reprise ou do réaction ultérieure.

Nous pensons avoir exprimé assez nettement notre opinion a ce sujet, surtout dan nos Circulaires de la semaine dernière. Ans, pouvons nous simplement ajouter qu'a notre sens la situation du marché est maintenait saine et que saut événements imprévus, il n' a pas de danger de nouvelle dépression sériesse Pour l'instant, les bas prix de la cote sent prit cipalement imputables à l'approche de la mort saison, qui provoque d'ordinaire une accalmie dans les transactions et détermina on' tass ment des cours. Os, suivant toutes les app. renoes; csox-ci on1', d'ores et déja, atteint pour la généralité des valeurs tout au moins les limites rationnelles delà baisse.

Il do s'ensuit pis naturellement, qu'il faille s'attendre à une hausse immédiate; maisl'ooc sion est peut être propice pour prendre position sur plusieurs titres qui bénéficieront assur meut, d'ici à la rentrée, d'uno plus-value iu portante.

Pour ce qui est de nous amener a imprimer ici dos pronostics spéciaux sur tel ou, tel titre nous ne saurions raisonablement condescend) a ce decir de quelques nus de nos lecteur Tout an plus pouvons-nous leur fournir indications utiles par voie de correspondant privée.

Nous croyons être en mesure de déclarer, c la manière la plus positive, que la nouvelle lancée avant hier par un journal d'Alexandrie savoir qu'il e t question d'an fractionnement des actions de la National Bank of Egypt, est dénuée de fondement
Les steamers que l'Express Nile Steamers Co. a commandés en Angleterre seront prêts en automne, do manière que la transport di voyageurs sur le Nil paisse être inauguré l'entrée de l'hiver prochain.

On suit qu'un service hebdomadaire de b teaux touristes sera organisé entre le Caire i é Luxor, avec no arrêt do trois jours dans cette dernière localité, et un service journalier entre Luxor et Assouan. La flottille sera placée soi la direction d'un homme des pins compétent qui, par une longue expérience acquise dans pays, connaît tons lo» rouages et les besoins 1 de does services. Le succès de l'entreprise peut a donc, d'ores et déja, être considéré cornu assuré.

Aussi ne faut-il pas attacher de l'importance la circonstance que l'action est cotée au-dessous du pair. Cette particularité, d'ailleurs commune a maint autre titre nouveau, est absolument d'ordre transitoire et doit être attribues d'absord a la situation actuelle du marche ensuite a l'appel du deuxième versement enfin au fait que certains apiculteurs a l'affut d'un petit benefice immédiat, liquident leur souscription pour s'assurer le profit provenant des parts de fondateur qui leur ont été allouées.

La valeur intrinsèque de l'action et les perspectives de l'affaire ne se trouvent nullement modifiées de ce chef. Tout au contraire, les acheteurs sérieux profiteront assurément de l'occasion pour s'intéresser a meilleur compte a un titre appelé à acquérir une plan value certaine.

L'assemblée générale ordinaire de la Nile Cold Storage Co., qui a eu lieu au Caire samedi passé, a approuvé les comptes et bilan de l'e- xercice écoulé. M. G. Royle a été élu adminis- 1 L'assemblée extraordinaire, tenue aussitôt après, a accepté on principe la réduction du capital social à £-10,000, ce qui ramènera la ! valeur nominale de l'action do £ l à 16 sh. Cette résolution sera soumise à la ratification ' d'une nouvelle assemblés qui se réunira dans un mois.

div.head:
AMERICAN NAVY
UNPREPARED FOR WAR.
NO RESERVE OF GUNS OR AMMUNITION

div.p: Rear-Admiral Mason, chief of the Naval Ordinance Department, declares that, owing to parsimony on the part of Congress, the Navy „ has no reserve of guns or ammunition, and that the latter is insufficient to lMt the whole navy for a three hours' action. War under these conditions would mean disaster. (Reuter)

The Japanese training squadron has arrived here and has had a magnificent reception. The city was decorated and a week's festivities have been arranged for by the Governor-General and the Lord Mayor, in which the British war- ships are participating. (Reuter)
Moorish brigands have seized and looted a British felucca, and are holding three Gibraltese for ransom. They also boarded an American steamer and removed the Moorish pas- sengers. (Reuter)
A Natal militia officer has arrived here in order to enroll a contingent of unemployed for service in Zululand. (Reuter)
News has been received here that the Shah of Persia is suffering severely from the extreme heat end acute gout. (Reuter)

div.head:
THE POPE'S ILLNESS.
COMPLICATED HEART AFFECTION.

div.p: It is reported that the Pope is suffering from a complicated heart affection. All audiences have been suspended. (Reuter)
The King to day invested Prince Arthur of Connaught with the Victorian Chain in recognition of his mission to Japan. (Reuter)
In the second ballots the Government group have gained thirty more seats. M. Deoulede and Colonel Marchand have been defeater Maltre Labori has been elected. (Reuter)
The French Government have had a net gain of 58 seats in the whole elections of which the Socialist groups have gained 46. The Nationalists were the heaviest losers. (Reuter)

The following are the complete results i the elections : 78 Liberal Conservatives, 5 Nationalists, 77 Progressives, 77 Republics] of the Left, 110 Radicals, 143 Socialist Rad oals, 56 United Socialists, 19 Independent Socialists, 1 Anti Socialist. (Havas)
Yesterday's explosion was quite accidental. (Havas)
M. Bouffides, Ministerialist, has been elected President of the Chamber. (Reuter)

div.head: U S A. CONSUL MURDERED AT BATOUM.

div.p: An Englishman named Stuart, United States Consul at Batoum, has been murdered. (Reuter)
The Queen has arrived here. (Reuter)

div.head:
ANGLO RUSSIAN AGREEMENT.
REPORTS MERE BALLONS D'ESSAI.

div.p: The "Times" describes the numerous reports of the Anglo-Russian agreement as mere ballons d'essai, and states that nothing whatever has been settled or can be settled until the internal situation, which demands superhuman state: manship, permits of a stable foreign policy. (Reuter)

The Tsar has informed the Duma that he cannot receive their address except throng] the intermediary of the Court Minister. The members are irritated, but have decided not to make his refusal the ground for conflict a present (Reuter)
Colonel Count Keller has been seriously injured by a bomb. The would be assassin escaped. (Reuter)

div.head: NEW ROLLING STOCK FOR STATE RAILWAYS.
div.p: We have on several occasions pointed out the energetic steps which are being taken by the State Railways in standardising their rolling stock. In May last we illustrated and described some 30 ton covered grain wagons and open coal trucks specially made for this service by the Leeds Forge Company. Those formed portions of a sample order, the introduction of which proved so satisfactory that the Egyptian State Railways placed a further order with the same firm for thirty open and thirty closed, wagons similar to those described by us. with the exception that the covered wagons are some 18 ius. higher than those of the sample order.

We now have occasion to illustrate a further order which has recently been shipped to Alexandria. This consists of thirty 40-ton bogie platform wagons and ten 30-ton bogie oil-tank wagons, to tho standard 4 ft. 8 1/2 in. gauge.

Both sets of wagons are provided with Pox's patent pressed steel underframes and bogies, similar to those of the wagons described in our former article. They have a length over buffers of 37 ft., a length over headstocks of 31 ft, and a width over solebars of 8 ft. 9 ins. The bogie wheels have a diameter on the tread of 2 ft. 9 1/2 ins., whilst the wheel base is 5 ft. 6 ins., and the distance between the bogie centres 23 ft The bogie platform wagons have a fare weight of 10 toes 17 cwts., and tho oil- tank wagons a "tare" of 17 tons 1 cwt. The platform wagons are fitted with steel floors, but are without aides or ends. The oil-tank wagons have a capacity of 836 cubic ft. and are capable of taking a load of 23 tons of petroleum.

The shell is composed of steel plates, 9-32nds of an inch in thickness, weighing 11 1/2 lbs. to the square foot. Each tank has been tested with a water pressure of 10 lbs. per square inch Tho tank is filled through a man- hole in the top, which is 1 ft. 6 ins. in diameter. They are emptied by means of pipes leading a gun metal cock at each side of the wagon, and also by means of a semi-rotary pomp at the end. The ,tanks are supported upon timber baulks, which-are bolted between steel cradles.

The whole tank is protected from the heat of the son by a light roofing of corrugated iron. In these days, when so much is being heard of the "superiority" of American-and other foreign-built railway rolling stock, it is interesting reto note that in October, 1904, a contract was placed with the Leeds Forge Company for 50 sets, or 100 bogies, with axle-boxes and springs, etc., for the Egyptian State Rail- ways, whilst twelve months later a "repeat" order was given to the same firm for an additional 100 sets, or 200 bogies, for Egypt. These bogies are for 30-ton wagons, and are being used to replace unsatisfactory American bogies which were built only two or three years ago.
("African Engineering ")

div.head: THE CASTLE OF AKABA
div.p: Akaba, about which so much has recently been heard, has, a correspondent points ont, a good deal of history. The castle was erected by Sultan El Ghusi of Egypt in the sixteenth century, and was in the possession of the Egyptians about a hundred years age, when Burckhardt, the celebrated Arabian traveller, visited it.

He says:-"The Pasha of Egypt keeps here a garrison of about thirty soldiers to guard the provisions deposited for the supply of the Hadj and for the use of the cavalry on their passage by this route to join the army in the Hedjaz The castle iB situated at an hour and a half or two hours from the western chain, down which the Hadj route leads, and about the same distance from the eastern chain.

It is a few hundred paces from the sea, and is surrounded by large groves of date trees. Burckhardt adds that the descent of the western mountain is very steep, and has probably given to the place its name of Akaba, which in Arabic means a cliff or "a going up"

There appears, too, to be little doubt that it is identical with the Ezion Geter of Scripture, the port of Solomon's navy. Into the plain which surrounds the castle on every side except the sea issues the Wady of Akaba, the broad sandy valley which leads towards the Dead Sea, and which in put ages probably formed the channel of the Jordan to the sea.

div.head: SUDAN DEATH ROLL
div.p: THE WHITE MAN'S BURDEN

Africa, more by reason of its olimate than of the temper/of its population, continues to levy a heavy toll on those strangers who, whether in the pursuit of gain, or, as in the instance cow under discussion, at the oall of doty, seek to penetrate far into its hitherto woll nigh inviolate precincts. From 1901 to 1904, both inolusive, 11 British officers, 2 British noncommissioned officers, and 32 Bgyptian or Sudanese officers died. Daring 1905 and the early part of 1906, Major. Bonlnois, Lieutenant Fell, Captain Sterling, Colour Sergeant Boardman, Mr. Barron, of the Geological 8srvey, Mr, Marsden, Deputy Inspector at Scnaar, and s:x Egyptian and Sudanese officers died. This,is a heavy death roll, when considered in relation to the small number of those. employed, and when it is also remembered that those who died were all men in the prime of life, specially selected for their physioat strength and for their pre- en mod capacity for resisting disease.

Neither does ths nomber of deaths ade- quately repro-ent the amount of national and personal sacrifice, for from 1901 to 1905, both ioclnsire, 10 British officera, 1 British non- commissioned officer, and 23 Egyptian and Sudanese officers were invalided from ill- hoalth. Farther, it cannot be doubted that many civil and military officials, who have neither succumbed n6r been invalided, have Buffered severely in health from the praise- worthy zeal with which they have performed their work under conditions of special hardship.

"I will not deny," says Lord Cromer in his last Report, "that the prize is worth the oust, bat there can be no manner of doabt that it is being dearly bought. All that can be said to console the mourners over the loss of these valuable young lives, which the onward march 6f Sudanese civilization has claimed as its victims, is that, as I firmly believe, their friends abd relatives will not have died in vain, for the noble cans in which they laid down their lives is bound ultimately to triumph."

div.head: TRADE OF PALESTINE
div.p: If Palestine could not bo described m flowing with milk ami honey last ypar, the report oi tbo British Consol (or that oonntry reveals (a financial contemporary observes) that at all events a very considerable stream of oranges and other agricultural products was produced by the Holy Land doring that period. The value of the exports of oranges from Jaffa in 1905 was no lees than £114 600 or £11.700 more than for 1901 and £17,6(0 more than the average value for the years 1901-5. Altogether the trade of Palestine had a prosperous period in 1905, the total exports amounting to £367,800, an increase of £72,500, or 24.5 por oent. on the figures for the preoeding year. Oranges were the staple export, and the trade is said to be steadily increasing.

The sime remark holds good os to the exports oi wine and spirits, the value of which amounted to £47,0C0, or £9,200 more than for the previous twelve mouths. The imports, on the other hand, amounted to £464,000, which is £9.300 less than for the previous year, but even this decline points to improved conditions in the country. Thus the value of the imports of rice have declined by £19.200, the result, no doabt, of the excellent harvest in Palestine, which during the past year has been able to export wheat and other foodstuffs. A further gratifying feature is that the imports of ootton goods, which in 1904 amounted to £180.000, havo risen by £20,(00 in 1905, and these goods are practically all obtained from Manchester ; although as they are im- ported to a very largd'extent via Beyrout they fignre under the head of imports from Tarkiy instead of from the United Kingdom.

div.head: THE COTTON OUTLOOK
div.p: The prospects of the supply of American ootton next season are, says a Manchester correspondent, fairly good. It is rather soon to think of any figures, but given good weather ths yield will, it is hoped, be about 13,('00,000 bale. Egypt is not looking very well. Plant- ing has been, it is thought, overdone on the isame soil. The British Cotton-Growing Asso- ciation is full of hope, and is working aw*y in the Colonies, but it will be a long time before we get large crops. Cotton pieoe goods are moving in a healthy way, but there is no groat flow of businos. Some fear that f cotton keeps up in prioe there may be slackness in weaving later on in the year. American yarns are, it is feared, likely to be over supplied, ss many row mills are jest starting wbrk in the Oldham district Egyp- tian yarns, too, are not doing so well os a month or so ago. Another new company has been formed at Wigan to erect a mill to hold 60,000 ring spindles, and 55,000 mole spindles.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN PASHT
div.p: A great many years ago the people of Egypt, who had many idols, worshipped the cat among others. They thought she was like the moon, became she wss more active at night pad because her eyes changed like thi moty, which is sometimes full, and at othe times only alight crescent, or as we say, i half moon. 8o they mado sn idol with a oat' head, and named it Pasht. The same nami they gave to the moon, for the word mean "tho face of the moon." Tbe word has beei charged to "Pas" and "Pos," and ljss' oom at last to be "Puss. " the name the most' of us give to the cat Puss and pnssy-eat are pe name for kitty anywhere now. But few thin! of the name as given to her thousands of years ago and c\of the people who then bowed down and prayed to her.

div.head: CREDIT LYONNAIS
div.p: Société Anonyme
Capital 250,000,000 de francs
Entièrement Versés
Agences d'Égypte:
Alexandrie, Le Caire, Port-Said
Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que:
Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.
